result.markdown:
---
title: "MATH167R: Vectorized functions and lists"
author: "Peter Gao"
format: 
  revealjs:
    theme: [./slides.scss, ../theme.scss]
editor: visual
---


## Warm-up

Discuss the following lines of code. What do they do?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- c(3 > 4, T, 5 > 6)
y <- c(1, 0, 1)
rbind(x, y)
```
:::


. . .

**Answer:**


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- c(3 > 4, T, 5 > 6)
y <- c(1, 0, 1)
rbind(x, y)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  [,1] [,2] [,3]
x    0    1    0
y    1    0    1
```
:::
:::


## Overview of today

-   Vectorized functions
-   Lists
-   Data frames

# Vectorized functions

## Vector Arithmetic

**Vectorization**, or applying functions across vectors/arrays, is one of R's most powerful capabilities


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x <- 1:5
y <- -1:-5
y
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] -1 -2 -3 -4 -5
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
x + y
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 0 0 0 0 0
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
x * y
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1]  -1  -4  -9 -16 -25
```
:::
:::


## Vector Arithmetic

Be careful! R **recycles**, repeating elements of shorter vectors to match longer vectors. This is incredibly useful when done on purpose, but can also easily lead to hard-to-catch bugs in your code!


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
2 * x
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1]  2  4  6  8 10
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
c(1, -1) * x
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1]  1 -2  3 -4  5
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
c(1, -1) + x
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 2 1 4 3 6
```
:::
:::


## Vector Arithmetic

We can apply many functions component-wise to vectors, including comparison operators.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x >= 3
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
y < -2
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
(x >= 3) & (y < -2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
x == c(1, 3, 2, 4, 5)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1]  TRUE FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE
```
:::
:::


## Boolean Vectors

In code, entries that are `TRUE` or `FALSE` are called **booleans** (logicals in R). These are incredibly important, because they can be used to give your computer conditions. What will the following code do?


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
x[x > 3] <- 3
x
```
:::


. . .


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 1 2 3 3 3
```
:::
:::


## Boolean Vectors

We can also do basic arithmetic with booleans. `TRUE` is encoded as `1` and `FALSE` is encoded as `0`.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# First reset x
x <- 1:5
sum(x >= 3)
```
:::


. . .


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 3
```
:::
:::


. . .


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mean(x >= 3)
```
:::


. . .


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 0.6
```
:::
:::


. . .

What is this last quantity telling us?

. . .

By taking the mean, we are looking at the **proportion** of our vector that is `TRUE`!

## Complicated indexing

We can also get more complicated with our indexing.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Return the second and third elements of 
y[c(2, 3)]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] -2 -3
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Return the values of x greater than 3
x[x >= 3]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 3 4 5
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Values of x that match the index of the values of y that are less than -2
x[y < -2]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 3 4 5
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# which() returns the index of entries that are TRUE
which(y < -2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 3 4 5
```
:::
:::


## Complicated indexing

We can compare entire vectors using `identical()`


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
identical(x, -rev(y))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] FALSE
```
:::
:::


What do you think the function `rev()` is doing in the code above?

*Hint:* Use `?rev` to read the help files for the function

# Lists

## Lists

**Lists**, like vectors and matrices, are a class of objects in R. Lists are special because they can store multiple different types of data.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_list <- list("some_numbers" = 1:5,
                "some_characters" = c("a", "b", "c"),
                "a_matrix" = diag(2))
my_list
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
$some_numbers
[1] 1 2 3 4 5

$some_characters
[1] "a" "b" "c"

$a_matrix
     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    0
[2,]    0    1
```
:::
:::


Make sure to store items within a list using the `=` operator for assigning arguments, not `<-`!

## Accessing List Elements

There are three ways to access an item within a list

-   double brackets `[[]]` with its name in quotes
-   double brackets `[[]]` with its index as a number
-   dollar sign `$` followed by its name without quotes


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_list[["some_numbers"]]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 1 2 3 4 5
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
my_list[[1]]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 1 2 3 4 5
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
my_list$some_numbers
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 1 2 3 4 5
```
:::
:::


## Why double brackets?

If you use a single bracket to index, like we do with matrices and vectors, you will return a **list** with a single element.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_list[1]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
$some_numbers
[1] 1 2 3 4 5
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
my_list[[1]]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 1 2 3 4 5
```
:::
:::


Note that this means you can only return a single item in a list using double brackets or the dollar sign! (Why?)

## Why double brackets?

This is a subtle but important difference!


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_list[1] + 1
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error}
```
Error in my_list[1] + 1: non-numeric argument to binary operator
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_list[[1]] + 1
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 2 3 4 5 6
```
:::
:::


## Subsetting a list

You can subset a list similarly to vectors and matrices using single brackets.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_list[1:2]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
$some_numbers
[1] 1 2 3 4 5

$some_characters
[1] "a" "b" "c"
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
my_list[-2]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
$some_numbers
[1] 1 2 3 4 5

$a_matrix
     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    0
[2,]    0    1
```
:::
:::


## Adding to a list {.smaller}

We can use the same tools we used to access list elements to add to a list. However, if we use double brackets, we must use quotes, otherwise R will search for something that does not yet exist.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_list$a_boolean <- FALSE
my_list[["a_list"]] <- list("recursive" = TRUE)
my_list
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
$some_numbers
[1] 1 2 3 4 5

$some_characters
[1] "a" "b" "c"

$a_matrix
     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    0
[2,]    0    1

$a_boolean
[1] FALSE

$a_list
$a_list$recursive
[1] TRUE
```
:::
:::


## Names of List Items

Call `names()` to get a vector of list item names.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
names(my_list)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] "some_numbers"    "some_characters" "a_matrix"        "a_boolean"      
[5] "a_list"         
```
:::
:::


## Why bother?

-   Lists give us **key-value pairs**, also known as **dictionaries** or **associative arrays**
-   This means we can look up items in a list by name, rather than location
-   For example, if we know we are looking for `output` within a list, we can always search for it, regardless of how the list was created or what else it contains

# Data Frames

## Data frames

A **data frame** in R is essentially a special type of list, where each item is a vector of equal length. Typically, we say that data has $n$ rows (one for each **observation**) and $p$ columns (one for each **variable**)

Unlike a matrix, columns can have different types. However, many column functions still apply! (such as `colSums`, `summary`, etc.)

## Creating a data frame

An easy way to create a data frame is to use the function `data.frame()`.

Like lists, make sure you define the names using `=` and not `<-`!


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_data <- data.frame("var1" = 1:3,
                      "var2" = c("a", "b", "c"),
                      "var3" = c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE))
my_data
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  var1 var2  var3
1    1    a  TRUE
2    2    b FALSE
3    3    c  TRUE
```
:::
:::


## Creating a data frame

If you import or create numeric data as a `matrix`, you can also convert it easily using `as.data.frame()`


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_matrix <- matrix(1:9, nrow = 3, ncol = 3)
my_matrix
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    4    7
[2,]    2    5    8
[3,]    3    6    9
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
as.data.frame(my_matrix)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  V1 V2 V3
1  1  4  7
2  2  5  8
3  3  6  9
```
:::
:::


## Subsetting data frames

We can subset data frames using most of the tools we've learned about subsetting so far. We can use keys or indices.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_data$var1
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 1 2 3
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
my_data["var1"]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  var1
1    1
2    2
3    3
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
my_data[["var1"]]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 1 2 3
```
:::
:::


## Subsetting data frames


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_data[1]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  var1
1    1
2    2
3    3
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
my_data[[1]]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 1 2 3
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
my_data[, 1]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 1 2 3
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
my_data[1, ]
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  var1 var2 var3
1    1    a TRUE
```
:::
:::


## Adding to a data frame

We can add to a data frame using `rbind()` and `cbind()`, but be careful with type mismatches! We can also add columns using the column index methods.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# These all do the same thing
my_data <- cbind(my_data, "var4" = c(3, 2, 1))
my_data$var4 <- c(3, 2, 1)
my_data[, "var4"] <- c(3, 2, 1)
my_data[["var4"]] <- c(3, 2, 1)
my_data
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  var1 var2  var3 var4
1    1    a  TRUE    3
2    2    b FALSE    2
3    3    c  TRUE    1
```
:::
:::


## Adding to a data frame


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
rbind(my_data, c(1, 2, 3, 4))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  var1 var2 var3 var4
1    1    a    1    3
2    2    b    0    2
3    3    c    1    1
4    1    2    3    4
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
rbind(my_data, list(4, "d", FALSE, 0))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  var1 var2  var3 var4
1    1    a  TRUE    3
2    2    b FALSE    2
3    3    c  TRUE    1
4    4    d FALSE    0
```
:::
:::


## Investigating a data frame

We can use `str()` to see the structure of a data frame (or any other object!)


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
my_data2 <- rbind(my_data, c(1, 2, 3, 4))
str(my_data2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
'data.frame':	4 obs. of  4 variables:
 $ var1: num  1 2 3 1
 $ var2: chr  "a" "b" "c" "2"
 $ var3: num  1 0 1 3
 $ var4: num  3 2 1 4
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
my_data2 <- rbind(my_data, list(4, "d", FALSE, 0))
str(my_data2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
'data.frame':	4 obs. of  4 variables:
 $ var1: num  1 2 3 4
 $ var2: chr  "a" "b" "c" "d"
 $ var3: logi  TRUE FALSE TRUE FALSE
 $ var4: num  3 2 1 0
```
:::
:::


## Investigating a data frame

Most data frames will have column names describing the variables. They can also include rownames, which we can add using `rownames()`.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
rownames(my_data2) <- c("Obs1", "Obs2", "Obs3", "Obs4")
my_data2
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
     var1 var2  var3 var4
Obs1    1    a  TRUE    3
Obs2    2    b FALSE    2
Obs3    3    c  TRUE    1
Obs4    4    d FALSE    0
```
:::
:::


## Example data frames in R {.smaller}

There are plenty of free datasets available through R and its packages. If you haven't already, run `install.packages("palmerpenguins")` in your console. Then, we can load the `penguins` dataset.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# load palmer penguins package
library(palmerpenguins)

# open penguins data as a data frame
data(penguins)
penguins <- as.data.frame(penguins)
```
:::


## Penguins data {.smaller}

We can use the `head` function to look at the first several rows:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
head(penguins)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  species    island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
1  Adelie Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181        3750
2  Adelie Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186        3800
3  Adelie Torgersen           40.3          18.0               195        3250
4  Adelie Torgersen             NA            NA                NA          NA
5  Adelie Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193        3450
6  Adelie Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190        3650
     sex year
1   male 2007
2 female 2007
3 female 2007
4   <NA> 2007
5 female 2007
6   male 2007
```
:::
:::


-   How many columns are in this dataset?
-   How many rows are in this dataset?

## Penguins data {.smaller}

Using the `$` operator, we can access individual columns.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
penguins$bill_length_mm
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  [1] 39.1 39.5 40.3   NA 36.7 39.3 38.9 39.2 34.1 42.0 37.8 37.8 41.1 38.6 34.6
 [16] 36.6 38.7 42.5 34.4 46.0 37.8 37.7 35.9 38.2 38.8 35.3 40.6 40.5 37.9 40.5
 [31] 39.5 37.2 39.5 40.9 36.4 39.2 38.8 42.2 37.6 39.8 36.5 40.8 36.0 44.1 37.0
 [46] 39.6 41.1 37.5 36.0 42.3 39.6 40.1 35.0 42.0 34.5 41.4 39.0 40.6 36.5 37.6
 [61] 35.7 41.3 37.6 41.1 36.4 41.6 35.5 41.1 35.9 41.8 33.5 39.7 39.6 45.8 35.5
 [76] 42.8 40.9 37.2 36.2 42.1 34.6 42.9 36.7 35.1 37.3 41.3 36.3 36.9 38.3 38.9
 [91] 35.7 41.1 34.0 39.6 36.2 40.8 38.1 40.3 33.1 43.2 35.0 41.0 37.7 37.8 37.9
[106] 39.7 38.6 38.2 38.1 43.2 38.1 45.6 39.7 42.2 39.6 42.7 38.6 37.3 35.7 41.1
[121] 36.2 37.7 40.2 41.4 35.2 40.6 38.8 41.5 39.0 44.1 38.5 43.1 36.8 37.5 38.1
[136] 41.1 35.6 40.2 37.0 39.7 40.2 40.6 32.1 40.7 37.3 39.0 39.2 36.6 36.0 37.8
[151] 36.0 41.5 46.1 50.0 48.7 50.0 47.6 46.5 45.4 46.7 43.3 46.8 40.9 49.0 45.5
[166] 48.4 45.8 49.3 42.0 49.2 46.2 48.7 50.2 45.1 46.5 46.3 42.9 46.1 44.5 47.8
[181] 48.2 50.0 47.3 42.8 45.1 59.6 49.1 48.4 42.6 44.4 44.0 48.7 42.7 49.6 45.3
[196] 49.6 50.5 43.6 45.5 50.5 44.9 45.2 46.6 48.5 45.1 50.1 46.5 45.0 43.8 45.5
[211] 43.2 50.4 45.3 46.2 45.7 54.3 45.8 49.8 46.2 49.5 43.5 50.7 47.7 46.4 48.2
[226] 46.5 46.4 48.6 47.5 51.1 45.2 45.2 49.1 52.5 47.4 50.0 44.9 50.8 43.4 51.3
[241] 47.5 52.1 47.5 52.2 45.5 49.5 44.5 50.8 49.4 46.9 48.4 51.1 48.5 55.9 47.2
[256] 49.1 47.3 46.8 41.7 53.4 43.3 48.1 50.5 49.8 43.5 51.5 46.2 55.1 44.5 48.8
[271] 47.2   NA 46.8 50.4 45.2 49.9 46.5 50.0 51.3 45.4 52.7 45.2 46.1 51.3 46.0
[286] 51.3 46.6 51.7 47.0 52.0 45.9 50.5 50.3 58.0 46.4 49.2 42.4 48.5 43.2 50.6
[301] 46.7 52.0 50.5 49.5 46.4 52.8 40.9 54.2 42.5 51.0 49.7 47.5 47.6 52.0 46.9
[316] 53.5 49.0 46.2 50.9 45.5 50.9 50.8 50.1 49.0 51.5 49.8 48.1 51.4 45.7 50.7
[331] 42.5 52.2 45.2 49.3 50.2 45.6 51.9 46.8 45.7 55.8 43.5 49.6 50.8 50.2
```
:::
:::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
